reviewText:
Time clickers is done by these two people http://www.protonstudio.com/p/about-us.html

Basically its a solo version of the steam monster sale game. It advertises itself as a game that can be played in the background while your playing other games. This is both true and misleading. While it is true that you can flick the game in the back ground and have it work for you while your not looking at it, the game is designed so that your ai stand in constantly needs your helping hand. It seems your ai will never be smart enough to know how to get past the next boss.

Concept: Basically your there to wage war against cubes with health that do nothing more than just stand there and look cube like. You have 5 ai's at your disposal to help you shredder these cubes. These cubes dont fight back, they dont move, they are just in the way of you getting to the next level. Every 10 levels you will come across a boss every 5 levels a mini boss. The only thing that makes these things slightly harder is that they are accompanied by a time line needing to be met if you are to destroy them. If you fail to destroy them in the time necessary don't worry about it the timer will respawn and the boss will respawn as it did to begin with. Hence the only thing you need to do is buy and upgrade weapons and thats it. You don't even need to aim.

After you have reached level 100 you will have access to 10 time cubes which you can spend on a time cube skill tree which means restarting from the beginning again or you can go further after you have passed level 100 and try and collect as many time cubes as possible. So with all that in mind what is the point of all this? There isnt any. Its a complete time waster. By no means does this mean that it is a bad product though. Its very colorful and vibrant in fact with all the explosions and gold coins flying around you will feel like you have just witnessed a rocket launcher going off  at a casino.

It could have been enhanced to be more of a meaningful game such as making a co-op mode or even having the blocks move and have defense mechanism's or even having a consequence when you fail other than the boring yawn restart and do it again.

Still it's the first time i've ever played a game where a cube with a quinttrillion health points blocks my access from the next level, no need to panic though it seems my pistol does 1quintzillion damage points and the next upgrade contains a number too large for my brain to comprehend.

reviewText: Incremental games, or Clickers, are an odd bunch of time sinks, and I‚Äôve played a lot of them. From Cookie Clicker, to Clicker Heroes, to AdVenture Capitalist, there are few I haven‚Äôt at least booted up. Time Clickers is my favorite of them all. reviewText:
By far the very best free game I've ever played.

The devs are very attentive to the freedback and needs of the players. If there are any issues with the game, they immediately (and I do mean immediately) investigate the issue. If an issue is found, they respond swiftly to resolve it. They're always happy to help players out with problems they're having, or even if they're having a little trouble understanding something about the game. (I know I've misunderstood a few things and felt like a complete idiot, but they never treated me as such.)

The devs have another game here on Steam that I believe they give equal attention to. It doesn't seem like they favor Time Rifters (their paid game) over Time Clickers, but I don't know for sure because I've yet to save up enough to buy Time Rifters.

This game doesn't even have a cash shop! There is absolutely no way to advance by paying real money! Now, if you play the mobile app (which you can link to your Steam copy via cloud saves) you can opt in to watch ads for bonus gold, time cubes, and weapon cubes (when the rainbow ball shows up) but it is completely optional! Don't want to watch a really short ad? No problem! Just opt out of the ad experience in the options menu, and you'll just get gold whenever a rainbow ball appears (which is all you get on the PC version).

This game is aesthetically interesting but also pleasing. However, it's not for all, and some machines might not like the beautifully animated fireworks and such. Well, you don't have to worry about that! You can simply adjust the options to better suit you and your PC without making the overall graphics quality go way down.

This is definitely one of those increment games where you'll have to start over a whole lot, but gain something by doing so. (One thing to note is that in this game, even the time cubes you spend will continue granting a bonus, so you don't have to save up a bunch and not spend them to get a nice big boost.) While I do tend to overall enjoy the genre, I often find the starting over rather annoying. Time Clickers does a fantastic job with making it a lot less annoying. Just remember to put points into starting out with more gold as you keep playing, and things'll be fine. (If you don't, it'll slowly become a miserably slow grind every single time.)

Better yet, you can completely reset your stats without being forced to pay real money to be able to and without having to completely wipe out or edit your save file!

The devs even give us small holiday events!

Time Clickers is easily the best free game on Steam, and easily one of my all-time favorite games, free or paid for.

The devs have been doing a fantastic job and I very much look forward to seeing what they come out with in the future. I also very much look forward to the day when I get my hands on Time Rifters!

reviewText:
Is this even technically a game?

This title works fine to do what it sets out to do.
You can idly shoot at blocks and get points.
Those points upgrade passive guns that do the work for you, and get you more points.

It feels like it was made for laughs over the course of a weekend.

An interesting 'clicker' game with a twist.

It has all the usual features you would expect, quite similiar to 'Clicker Heroes' with bosses, minibosses, abilities etc, All wraped up in a 'first-person' clicking format. Different cubes that make up the enemy have different health points which makes it interesting so that you can concentrate your fire onto those, while your random/spread shooters pick off the less armoured cubes.

The game also features a rather extensive upgrading system, similiar to others where you reset your progress and start over with Time Cubes, to spend on upgrade trees. This adds a good bit of depth to the game and gives you the choice to upgrade how you think is best and play it to better suit your style.

Lots of achievements and time to be spent on what is yet another fun free clicking game on Steam.

reviewText:
As I played Pok√©mon Alpha Sapphire and Omega Ruby, my memories of certain trainers‚Äô one-liners and their Pok√©mon teams came rushing back from my time with the original Pok√©mon Sapphire and Ruby in 2002. Experiencing this classic role-playing game again in beautified 3D was truly a nostalgic trip, from the cute friendship-themed plot to the touching end-credits sequence. However, as a remake, it does represent a big missed opportunity to fix several significant balance issues and mechanical problems ‚Äî the difficulty I had going back after playing the much more modern Pok√©mon X shows how far Pok√©mon games have come in 12 years.

For the uninitiated, Ruby and Sapphire were the third installments in the Pok√©mon RPG series and the best-selling Game Boy Advance games of all time. They follow the tried-and-true Pok√©mon model of journeying to catch new monsters, challenging eight boss-like Gyms, and eventually fighting the Elite Four trainers and the Champion. Like most other Pok√©mon games they also put you at odds with a villainous team of Pok√©mon trainers, in this instance Team Magma for Ruby and Team Aqua for Sapphire, who want to use legendary Pok√©mon to forever change the region of Hoenn, where the games are set.

Now they‚Äôre the first of the earlier games to receive the 3D treatment. Generation III was a big change from the first two for many reasons, most notably the introduction of Abilities (attributes that add advantages to battle, among other things), Natures (which affect how stats develop) and double battles (using two Pok√©mon at once was unheard of back in the day). Different areas had their own weather patterns, and the region contained varied topography, from a desert to a volcano to sandy beaches.

In 2002 I reveled in the newness and feel of having an untouched world to explore, and that sense of wonder carries over in Omega and Alpha. The scenery is rich, the adorable characters are even more adorable (especially little Wally!), and there‚Äôs more to many of the cities than there was before. I walked into Mauville City for the first time while playing Alpha and didn‚Äôt even recognize it. In the original games it was comparatively small and boasted only the bike shop and the Game Corner, but now it‚Äôs like a smaller Lumiose City from X and Y: full of little shops and tons of NPCs to chat with. I actually got lost in Mauville City more than once, and had a lot of fun rediscovering something I thought I knew well.

Alpha and Omega also bear some resemblance to X and Y in that certain app-like features ‚Äî Pok√©mon Amie, Super Training, the Player Search System ‚Äî have all been integrated as part of the Pok√©Nav Plus. The interface is overcrowded as a result and really cumbersome, but the online apps are welcome additions (especially Wonder Trade) It‚Äôs the new Pok√©mon search app, the DexNav, that is perhaps the most interesting addition for Pok√©philes. Every so often, a wild Pok√©mon will peek its ears or tail out of the tall grass (or sand or water), and DexNav will alert you to things like the Pok√©mon‚Äôs level, ability, and even rare moves it might have. I found two Poochyena this way: a female with Ice Fang and a male with Poison Fang, two ‚Äúegg moves‚Äù that you can usually only get by carefully breeding. Easy-access breeding material! The app has the potential to help EV trainers as well, since you can see what Pok√©mon you‚Äôll face before you battle it, and in that regard it provides another alternative to Super Training aside from traditional, less-accessible methods.

There‚Äôs also an updated Berry map, first introduced in Gen IV, which is a serious help to anyone who needs Berries for competitive battle... or even Pok√©blocks! Remember Pok√©blocks? They help your Pok√©mon up their beauty or cuteness or what have you for Contests, which are of course a part of Alpha and Omega. These Pok√©mon talent shows have a Japanese pop-idol feel this time, which makes it all seem more modern and updated. Playing as the female trainer, I was literally and figuratively taken under the wing of number-one Contest star Lisia and her Altaria, Ali. Lisia is absolutely adorable, but the best part of Contests for me is undoubtedly the Cosplay Pikachu you receive after winning your first one. Change Pikachu‚Äôs outfit according to the five Contest attributes and Pikachu gets a different move! I might just be a super nerd, but it‚Äôs the best thing since Surfing Pikachu.

Really, all the tweaks of original Hoenn features are improvements. Unfortunately, there are still a few big flaws that weren‚Äôt addressed, and they‚Äôre even more noticeable in light of more recent Pok√©mon RPGs. My least favorite part of every Pok√©mon game is the unnecessary inclusion of too many hidden moves, commonly referred to as HMs (Hidden Machines), which you must teach to your Pok√©mon in order to progress through the region and aren‚Äôt so easily unlearned. Anything more than Surf and Fly is too much, as far as I‚Äôm concerned, and Hoenn is one of the worst HM offenders. Alpha and Omega dropped Flash for a total of seven HMs this time around ‚Äî and in the late-game you can summon Latias or Latios to fly you places, which means you won‚Äôt need a Pok√©mon in your team with Fly ‚Äî but compared to X and Y‚Äôs five HMs, it‚Äôs obvious why the decision was made to pare them back in subsequent games.

Secret Power factors into this too. It isn‚Äôt an HM, but it is another move that interacts with the overworld and is necessary for building Super Secret Bases. Maybe I‚Äôm just stingy with what moves I teach my Pok√©mon, but I wish I didn‚Äôt need a move at all to check out potential bases during my travels. That aside, having a home base I could decorate in 3D was a lot of fun, and sharing via StreetPass or setting it up for other players to fight through as a mini-Gym are both neat touches.

It‚Äôs not a new complaint, but Hoenn is still imbalanced type-wise, heavily favoring water. It‚Äôs especially noticeable in Alpha Sapphire, in which Team Aqua (the villains of the piece) use a lot of water types. It feels like there are water Pok√©mon in nearly every battle, and I have an overleveled Pikachu to show for it. You also have to navigate many bodies of water, since much of the late-game involves the HMs Surf and Dive to get from place to place. Diving was really neat back in 2002 when it was new, but I found it incredibly tedious in Alpha and Omega ‚Äî an obvious example of how superfluous some HMs are.

The water itself is absolutely gorgeous with the new graphics and details, though. One of my favorite parts of the entire adventure was splashing through puddles that reflected the starry skies at night, and even diving was made better by seeing a school of Luvdisc swimming by. Building my Super Secret Base on the rainy Route 119 had an extra-comfy, drinking-tea-on-a-rainy-day feel. Everything in Hoenn, water or not, is either delightfully cute or strikingly beautiful, and I enjoyed seeing the entire region anew ‚Äî despite the tediousness associated with navigating all that pretty water.

The Verdict
As a 3D remake, Pok√©mon Alpha Sapphire and Omega Ruby do a fantastic job of reintroducing Hoenn. Little details, like characters turning their heads to look as you pass or flocks of Wingulls flying overhead, make the region really come to life, and small updates and tweaks help make the journey smoother. Still, a few of its flaws are even more glaring in 3D, especially the excess water Pok√©mon and often dull navigation of their habitats. The added online features could help mitigate some of the type imbalances ‚Äî I‚Äôm a huge fan of Wonder Trade ‚Äî and there are even a few post-game surprises to encourage you to keep training well beyond the 25-hour main story.

7.8/10 - Too much water

This one is interesting. It is presented as a clicker game in the vein of Clicker Heroes and such, and definitely aims towards the same audience. It definitely feels like somebody without the necessary graphic design skills quickly put a game together to ride the successful Clicker Heroes wave.

They also decided that more is better and fill it up with all kinds of upgrades and achievement stuff.

If you want to grind away your time, just stay away from this one. Much more visually appealing stuff (adventure capitalist, tap heroes, clicker heroes) is around which offer a better experience. Avoid.

reviewText:
Normally, I find clicker games to be very calming. I have a lot of anxiety issues, and the simple mechanics and repetitive nature of clicker games gives me something to do that doesn't require a lot of brainpower.

Time Clickers is not like the other clicker games I have played.

First off, if you have photo-sensitive epilepsy, skip this game. Even when I used the simplest, most low-res graphics and animation options I could find in the menu, there was so much going on and so many flashing colors that I actually found myself feeling more stressed as I played. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I wasn't prepared for it, and like I said, if you have photo-sensitive epilepsy, it's probably not a good game for you.

Still, I like the idea of this game. Aside from the cosmetic differences, it is pretty much just like any other clicker game I've played. The damage bonuses and special upgrades are structured a little differently than I'd seen before, but it was easy enough to figure out. If you want a nice time-waster and don't mind the hectic, super-bright graphics, go ahead and pick it up. Personally, I'll be sticking to my more sedate clicker games, but it's really a personal preference thing.

reviewText:
Time Clickers is an incremental clicker/idle game.

Click to deal damage to blocks, eventually breaking them and earning some cash. Spend that cash on upgrades to your click damage. Purchase automatic damage over time, and upgrade that. Unlock special skills and use them to defeat enemies faster, or earn more cash per kill, and invest that cash into more upgrades so you can kill faster and get more cash to invest so you can kill faster and get more cash to invest so you can kill faster and get more cash to invest so you can kill faster and get more cash to invest so you can kill faster and get more cash to invest so you can kill faster and get more cash to invest...

Yep. It's one of these types of games. There's a prestige system that gives you a special currency that you can use to purchase various powerups that do a lot of things, such as decreasing skill cooldowns, increase gold dropped, increase dps,

To many people, this type of game seems boring. To those people, I'd suggest peeking at a few games like this to see what the appeal is. It's basically a distillation of most game genres that have some form of upgrade system, such as obtaining better gear or gaining levels and powerful perks.

Personally, I like these types of games. They satisfy that reward center in the brain. It's a perfect example of the Skinner Box.

reviewText:
A few weeks ago I stumbled upon the clicker/idle/incremental genre. AdVenture Capitalist hit me, and it hit me good. Now I found an even better one by the name of Time Clickers.

In similar games you will likely run into many, many brick walls - which will have you either buy real-money upgrades or quit that game for good. Time Clickers also has its brick walls. But you gain power aka damage fast enough to overcome them after the next few resets. In fact, it has no real-money shop - or I just haven't found it yet. Another difference is that offline-idling will not really get you anywhere in Time Clickers. You need to actually PLAY this game. And after 89 hours I'm nowhere near completing" it.

The final proof of how great this game is: It made me write my first review ever!

10/10 would time click again."
